subsection.p: In , we used linear regression to fit a line to a collection of data points. If the data points do not cluster around a line, it does not make sense to describe them by a linear function. Compare the scatterplots shown below.

subsection.title: Finding a Quadratic Function through Three Points
subsection.p: Every linear function can be written in the form y = mx + b To find a specific line, we must find values for the two parameters (constants) m and b. We need two data points in order to find those two parameters. A quadratic function, however, has three parameters, a, b, and c: y = ax^2 + bx + c To find these parameters, we need three data points. We then use the method of elimination to solve a system of three linear equations.

statement.p: Find values for a, b, and c so that the points (1, 3), (3, 5), and (4, 9) lie on the graph of ~y = ax^2 + bx + c.

solution.p: We substitute the coordinates of each of the three points into the equation of the parabola to obtain three equations: \begin{alignedat}{9} \alert{3} =\amp a(\alert{1})^2{}+{} \amp b(\alert{1}) \amp {}+{} \amp c \amp \\ \alert{5} =\amp a(\alert{3})^2{}+{} \amp b(\alert{3}) \amp {}+{} \amp c \amp \\ \alert{9} =\amp a(\alert{4})^2{}+{} \amp b(\alert{4}) \amp {}+{} \amp c \amp \end{alignedat} or, equivalently, \begin{alignedat}{9} a \amp {}+{} \amp b \amp {}+{} \amp c \amp {}={} \amp 3\amp\hphantom{blankblank} \amp(1)\\ 9a \amp {}+{} \amp 3b \amp {}+{} \amp c \amp {}={} \amp 5\amp\amp(2) \\ 16a \amp {}+{} \amp 4b \amp {}+{} \amp c \amp {}={} \amp 9\amp\amp(3) \end{alignedat} This is a system of three equations in the three unknowns a, b, and c. To solve the system, we first eliminate c. We substitute 1 for a in Equation (4) to find \begin{aligned}[t] 8(\alert{1}) + 2b \amp= 2 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Solve for }b.}\\ b \amp= -3 \end{aligned} Finally, we substitute -3 for b and 1 for a in Equation (1) to find \begin{aligned}[t] \alert{1} + (\alert{-3}) + c\amp = 3\amp\amp \blert{\text{Solve for }c.}\\ c \amp = 5 \end{aligned} Thus, the equation of the parabola is y = x^2 - 3x + 5 The parabola and the three points are shown below.

subsection.p: The simplest way to fit a parabola to a set of data points is to pick three of the points and find the equation of the parabola that passes through those three points.

subsection.title: Finding an Equation in Vertex Form
subsection.p: It is easier to find a quadratic model if one of the points we know happens to be the vertex of the parabola. In that case, we need only one other point, and we can use the vertex form to find its equation.

sidebyside.p: When Andre practices free-throws at the park, the ball leaves his hands at a height of 7 feet and reaches the vertex of its trajectory 10 feet away at a height of 11 feet, as shown at right.

li.p: Find a quadratic function for the ball's trajectory.
Do you think Andre's free-throw will score on a basketball court where the hoop is 15 feet from the shooter and 10 feet high?

If Andre's feet are at the origin, then the vertex of the ball's trajectory is the point (10, 11), and its y-intercept is (0, 7). Start with the vertex form for a parabola: \begin{aligned}[t] y \amp = a(x - x_v)^2 + y_v\\ y \amp= a(x - 10)^2 + 11 \end{aligned} We still need to know the value of a. We can substitute the coordinates of any point on the parabola for x and y and solve for a. We will use the point (0, 7): \begin{aligned}[t] 7 \amp= a(0 - 10)^2 + 11\\ 7 \amp= 100a + 11\\ a \amp= -0.04 \end{aligned} The equation of the trajectory is y = -0.04(x - 10)^2 + 11.

We would like to know if the point (15, 10) is on the trajectory of Andre's free-throw. Substitute x = 15 into the equation: \begin{aligned}[t] y \amp= -0.04(15 - 10)^2 + 11\\ \amp= -0.04(25) + 11 = 10 \end{aligned} Andre's shot will score.

statement.p: Francine records the height of the tip of the minute hand on the classroom’s clock at different times. The data are shown in the table, where time is measured in minutes since noon. (A negative time indicates a number of minutes before noon.) Find a quadratic regression equation for the data and use it to predict the height of the minute hand's tip at 40 minutes past noon. Do you believe this prediction is valid?

solution.p: We enter the time data under L_1 and the height data under L_2. Then we calculate and store the quadratic regression equation in Y_1, as we did in . The regression equation is y = -0.00297x^2 + 0x + 8.834 From either the graph of the regression equation or from the table (see figure below), we can see that the fit is not perfect, although the curve certainly fits the data better than any straight line could.

image.description: GC screens of graph and tables for quadratic fit

solution.p: If we scroll down the table, we find that this equation predicts a height of approximately 4.08 feet at time 40 minutes. (See figure (c).) This is a preposterous estimate! The position of the minute hand at 40 minutes after noon should be the same as it was exactly one hour earlier (at 20 minutes before noon), when it was 7.50 feet.

subsection.p: Using the wrong type of function to fit the data is a common error in making predictions. We know that the minute hand of a clock repeats its position every 60 minutes. The graph of the height of its tip oscillates up and down, repeating the same pattern over and over. We cannot describe such a graph using either a linear or a quadratic function.

image.description: parabola fit on part of a periodic wave

sidebyside.p: The graph of the height is shown at left, along with the graph of our quadratic regression equation. You can see that the regression equation fits the actual curve only on a small interval.

subsection.p: Your calculator can always compute a regression equation, but that equation is not necessarily appropriate for your data. Choosing a reasonable type of regression equation for a particular data set requires knowledge of different kinds of models and the physical or natural laws that govern the situation at hand.
